definitions: accompanying but subordinate to something else that is primary or main
running side by side or parallel in position, time, or significance
serving as security or guarantee for repayment of a loan
examples: The medication had several collateral effects on her health
Collateral damage from the storm affected neighboring properties
The two roads run in collateral directions through the valley
These collateral developments happened during the same time period
The bank required collateral property to secure the business loan
She used her jewelry as collateral for the emergency funds

definitions: considered valuable or interesting enough to be worth collecting as hobby
capable of being collected, gathered, or obtained from someone
examples: These vintage stamps are highly collectable among philatelists
The artist's early works have become increasingly collectable
The outstanding fees are collectable through legal action
All collectable data will be processed by the system

definitions: showing control over emotions and appearing calm in difficult situations
brought together in one place or gathered from various sources
examples: She remained collected despite the unexpected questioning
His collected manner impressed everyone during the crisis
The collected works of Shakespeare filled several volumes
All collected samples were sent to the laboratory

definitions: suitable or desirable for a collection due to rarity, beauty, or interest
capable of being collected or recovered, especially regarding payment
examples: These limited edition coins are highly collectible items
Vintage toys have become increasingly collectible over time
All outstanding debts are collectible within thirty days
The collectible amount was clearly stated on the invoice

definitions: giving priority to group goals over individual desires and emphasizing interdependence
examples: Their collectivist culture values family harmony above personal success
The collectivist approach emphasized community welfare over individual profit
Collectivist societies often have stronger social safety nets
His collectivist philosophy influenced the company's cooperative structure

definitions: marked by cooperation and respect among colleagues as equals
involving shared responsibility and authority among members of a group
examples: The department maintains a collegial atmosphere despite disagreements
Their collegial relationship made the project run smoothly
The committee uses a collegial decision-making process
The collegial governance structure gives all members equal voice

definitions: of, relating to, or typical of a college or college students
having authority or functions shared equally among colleagues
examples: The collegiate atmosphere on campus was energizing
She participated in several collegiate sports during university
The church operates under a collegiate system of leadership
Their collegiate approach ensured all departments had input

definitions: used in ordinary or familiar conversation rather than formal speech or writing
examples: His colloquial language made the lecture more accessible
The novel uses colloquial expressions to capture local speech
She avoided colloquial phrases in her academic paper
The dictionary includes many colloquial terms and idioms

definitions: settled or controlled by people from another country establishing a colony
completely taken over or dominated by something that spreads
examples: The colonised territories struggled for independence
Many colonised nations gained freedom in the twentieth century
The abandoned building was colonised by wild birds
Her thoughts were colonised by worries about work

definitions: established control over an area by settling people from another country
completely taken over or dominated by something that spreads rapidly
examples: The colonized regions maintained their cultural traditions
European powers colonized much of Africa and Asia
The empty lot was quickly colonized by wildflowers
Social media has colonized every aspect of modern life

definitions: having a row of columns supporting a roof or upper structure
examples: The colonnaded entrance gave the building classical elegance
They walked through the colonnaded courtyard in silence
The colonnaded facade reminded visitors of ancient temples
A colonnaded walkway connected the two main buildings

definitions: having a particular color or combination of colors rather than being colorless
influenced by personal feelings, opinions, or prejudices rather than facts
examples: She wore a brightly colored dress to the party
The colored pencils were arranged in rainbow order
His judgment was colored by previous bad experiences
The report was colored by the author's political views

definitions: having much or varied color that is bright and striking
full of interest, variety, and excitement in character or behavior
examples: The garden was filled with colorful flowers
She painted colorful murals on the classroom walls
He told colorful stories about his travels
The neighborhood has a colorful history of artistic expression

definitions: having no color or being transparent, pale, or drained of color
lacking distinctive character, interest, or vitality in personality or expression
examples: The colorless liquid turned blue when heated
Her face was colorless after hearing the news
His colorless delivery made the speech forgettable
The colorless prose failed to engage readers

definitions: extraordinarily large in size, extent, or degree beyond normal proportions
examples: The colossal statue towered over the city square
They faced a colossal challenge in rebuilding after the disaster
The project required colossal amounts of funding
Her colossal mistake cost the company millions

definitions: possessing hue, shade, or tint rather than being black, white, or transparent
influenced or affected by personal views, background, or emotions
examples: The colour photographs captured the sunset perfectly
She prefers colour films to black and white
His experiences colour his understanding of politics
Cultural background will colour anyone's interpretation

definitions: having a particular color or combination of colors as a distinguishing feature
affected by personal opinions, emotions, or prejudices rather than objectivity
examples: The coloured glass windows created beautiful patterns
She sorted the coloured laundry from the whites
His view was coloured by childhood experiences
The article was heavily coloured by political bias

definitions: having bright colors or a variety of colors that catch the eye
interesting and exciting with varied or unusual character and events
examples: The market displayed colourful fruits and vegetables
Children love colourful picture books
She has a colourful personality that lights up rooms
The town's colourful history includes pirates and treasures

definitions: lacking color or being transparent, white, or very pale
lacking character, interest, or distinctive features that engage attention
examples: The colourless solution needed a dye added
His face turned colourless when he heard the diagnosis
Her colourless performance disappointed the directors
The candidate gave colourless answers to every question

definitions: having the shape of a column or arranged in columns
examples: The columnar basalt formations were created by volcanic activity
The data was presented in columnar format for clarity
Columnar cacti can grow to impressive heights
The columnar structure of the cells was clearly visible

definitions: furnished or decorated with columns as architectural features
examples: The columned portico provided shade from the sun
They entered through the columned hall
The columned temple ruins attracted many tourists
A columned pavilion stood in the center of the garden

definitions: in a state of deep unconsciousness for a prolonged period
extremely lethargic, inactive, or unresponsive as if unconscious
examples: The patient remained comatose after the accident
Comatose victims require constant medical monitoring
After the huge meal, he lay comatose on the couch
The comatose economy showed no signs of recovery

definitions: engaged in or ready to engage in combat or fighting
examples: Combatant forces clashed at the border
The combatant nations finally agreed to peace talks
Non-combatant civilians were evacuated from the area
Both combatant parties suffered heavy losses

definitions: ready or eager to fight or argue in an aggressive manner
examples: His combative attitude made negotiations difficult
She became combative when her ideas were challenged
The combative tone of the debate alienated viewers
Years of competition made him increasingly combative

definitions: having hair arranged or styled using a comb
searched through carefully and systematically looking for something
examples: His neatly combed hair gleamed in the light
The combed cotton sheets felt incredibly soft
Police combed the area for evidence
Researchers combed through archives for historical documents

definitions: capable of catching fire and burning easily when exposed to flame
examples: Store combustible materials away from heat sources
The warehouse contained highly combustible chemicals
Dry leaves are particularly combustible in summer
Combustible gases require special handling procedures

definitions: having received consolation, support, or reassurance in distress
feeling relief from anxiety, grief, or pain through consolation
examples: The comforted child finally stopped crying
She felt comforted by her friend's presence
He was comforted knowing his family was safe
The comforted patients responded better to treatment

definitions: giving a feeling of relief, consolation, or encouragement in difficult times
examples: Her comforting words helped ease his anxiety
The comforting warmth of the fireplace welcomed them home
It's comforting to know help is available
She found the familiar routine comforting

definitions: amusing or funny, especially in an odd or whimsical way
examples: His comical expressions made everyone laugh
The situation was too comical to take seriously
The dog's comical attempts to catch its tail entertained us
She wore a comical hat to the costume party

definitions: having or showing authority that demands obedience and respect
having a dominant position that provides advantage or wide view
examples: Her commanding presence silenced the room
He spoke in a commanding tone
The castle has a commanding view of the valley
Their commanding lead made victory certain

definitions: serving to honor and preserve the memory of someone or something
examples: A commemorating plaque marks the historic site
The commemorating ceremony honored fallen soldiers
They issued commemorating stamps for the anniversary
The commemorating monument stands in the town square

definitions: intended to honor and preserve the memory of a person or event
examples: They released commemorative coins for the centennial
A commemorative service was held annually
The commemorative edition included rare photographs
She received a commemorative medal for her service

definitions: deserving praise and approval for being good or admirable
examples: Her commendable efforts raised thousands for charity
The team showed commendable dedication
His commendable honesty impressed the committee
They made commendable progress despite the obstacles

definitions: corresponding in size, extent, amount, or degree to something else
examples: Salary should be commensurate with experience
The punishment was commensurate with the crime
They received rewards commensurate to their contributions
The risk is commensurate with potential profits

definitions: organized and run primarily for financial profit rather than other values
examples: The festival has become too commercialised
Their commercialised approach lost artistic integrity
Once pristine beaches are now commercialised tourist spots
The commercialised sport lost its amateur spirit

definitions: developed or managed with emphasis on profit rather than other considerations
examples: The holiday has become highly commercialized
Their commercialized version lacks authentic flavor
The commercialized waterfront disappointed longtime residents
Art becomes less meaningful when commercialized

definitions: formally ordered or authorized to be made, done, or provided
having received a formal appointment to military officer rank
examples: The commissioned artwork hangs in the lobby
They commissioned a study on environmental impact
Newly commissioned officers attended the ceremony
Her commissioned rank came with new responsibilities

definitions: feeling dedication and loyalty to a cause, activity, or relationship
confined to a psychiatric hospital or similar institution by legal order
examples: She's committed to environmental protection
The committed volunteers work tirelessly
The patient was committed for observation
He was committed after the evaluation

definitions: offering plenty of room and space for comfort and convenience
examples: The commodious cabin easily accommodated eight guests
They moved to a more commodious apartment
The commodious trunk held all their luggage
A commodious armchair sat by the fireplace

definitions: occurring frequently and therefore not remarkable or interesting
examples: Such technology was commonplace in modern offices
Violent storms have become commonplace here
His commonplace observations added nothing new
The once exotic fruit is now commonplace

definitions: shared by all members of a community for common use
examples: The communal garden provides fresh vegetables
They gathered in the communal dining area
Communal property belongs to all residents equally
The tribe maintains communal farming traditions

definitions: able to be transmitted from one person or organism to another
examples: Measles is a highly communicable disease
They isolated patients with communicable infections
Some communicable diseases spread through air
Proper hygiene prevents communicable illness

definitions: ready and willing to talk, share information, or express thoughts and feelings
examples: The normally quiet child became more communicative
A communicative teacher encourages student participation
She's very communicative about her feelings
Communicative patients recover faster

definitions: closely and neatly packed together in a dense form
having all necessary features in a small, convenient size
examples: The compact snow was perfect for making snowballs
Compact soil doesn't drain well
This compact car is perfect for city driving
She carries a compact mirror in her purse

definitions: able to be likened to another of similar quality or nature
examples: The two products are comparable in quality
No comparable data exists from previous years
Their salaries are comparable to industry standards
These comparable houses sold for similar prices

definitions: relating to or using comparison between things
measured or judged by comparison rather than absolute standards
examples: The comparative study examined different cultures
She teaches comparative literature
They live in comparative luxury
The comparative safety of suburbs attracts families

definitions: feeling or showing sympathy and concern for others who suffer
examples: The compassionate nurse comforted worried families
Her compassionate response helped ease their grief
A compassionate society cares for its vulnerable
The judge showed compassionate consideration

definitions: able to exist or work together without conflict or problems
examples: The software is compatible with most operating systems
They were perfectly compatible as roommates
These plants are compatible in the same garden
Their compatible personalities made collaboration easy

definitions: given something, typically money, in recognition of loss, suffering, or injury
examples: Workers were compensated for overtime hours
The compensated volunteers received small stipends
Victims were fairly compensated for their losses
A well-compensated position attracted many applicants

definitions: having the necessary ability, knowledge, or skill to do something successfully
examples: She's a competent driver with years of experience
The competent staff handled the emergency well
He's competent in several programming languages
A competent teacher adapts to student needs
